0.referenceAnswer:
Supervised learning is <Point1:2>a
type of machine learning where the model is trained on labeled data <Point1:2>.

input-output pairs <Point2:2>.

10.question:
Explain the difference between 
classification and regression.
10.referenceAnswer:
Classification and regression<Point1:1>differ
in the type of output they predict <Point1:1>. <Point2:1>Classification
predicts discrete labels (categories)<Point2:1>，whereas<Point3:1>regression
predicts continuous quantities <Point3:1>.
10.studentAnswer: Regression predicts numerical outcomes, and classification predicts which category something belongs to.
10.feedback:
<Point1:mark> *True* (The student correctly identifies the fundamental difference in the output types between classification and regression, aligning with the reference answer.)

<Point2:mark> *True* (The student's answer accurately reflects that classification deals with predicting discrete labels, matching the reference.)

<Point3:mark> *True* (The student mentions that regression predicts numerical outcomes, which corresponds to predicting continuous quantities as stated in the reference answer.)

30.question: Define overfitting in machine learning.
30.referenceAnswer:
<Point1:2>Overfitting occurs when a machine learning model learns the details and noise in the training data to an extent<Point1:2>. 
<Point2:2>It negatively impacts the performance of the model on new data, making it less generalizable<Point2:2>.
30.studentAnswer: Overfitting is when your model learns too much from the training data, including the noises, so it doesn’t perform well on new data.
30.feedback:
<Point1:mark> *True* (The student's answer captures the essence of overfitting, acknowledging that the model learns the noise in the training data, which aligns with the first part of the reference answer.)

<Point2:mark> *True* (The student's answer also implies that this excessive learning from the training data leads to poor performance on unseen data, aligning with the second part of the reference answer about reduced generalization.)

39.question: Define overfitting in machine learning.
39.referenceAnswer:
<Point1:2>Overfitting occurs when a machine learning model learns the details and noise in the training data to an extent<Point1:2>. 
<Point2:2>It negatively impacts the performance of the model on new data, making it less generalizable<Point2:2>.
39.studentAnswer: Overfitting in machine learning is when a model becomes too specific to the training data, including its noise, and fails to perform well on new data.
39.feedback:
<Point1:mark> *True* (The student's answer captures the essence of overfitting, explaining that it involves a model becoming overly specific to the training data, including its noise.)

<Point2:mark> *True* (The student's answer also implies that this specificity leads to poor performance on unseen data, indicating the issue of generalizability, which aligns with the second point in the reference answer.)
